utterances: Think so (laughter).
But how would it go if he biked to work here in LA?
Well, Javier Panzar of the LA Times biked one potential route himself, and he put together a video.
(SOUNDBITE OF VIDEO)
All right, up ahead a few blocks - Venice Boulevard.
And let me tell you, it's not the best street in America for biking.
Panzar started out in LeBron's neighborhood, which is west of downtown LA, and he biked to the Staples Center.
So we called him up to see how it went.
If LeBron does do this ride, he'll experience everything from very new, nice, separated bike lanes and then unpaved, pothole-filled streets with no bike lanes at all.
Now, we should say, Panzar did make it downtown unscathed, but does he think LeBron is safe to take this path?
I don't think if you're a Lakers fan you're going to necessarily want LeBron biking to work every day.
Probably not since the team just invested in a four-year, $153 million contract with LeBron.
So King James, perhaps you should just stick to the elliptical.
(SOUNDBITE OF EL TEN ELEVEN'S ""THREE SIDES OF A COIN"")
Interesting analysis there from John, but besides us and the erudite DAY TO DAY audience, who is really watching this political race?
Well, NPR's Mike Pesca pays attention to the question of just who's paying attention.
Rudy Giuliani pounced on Ron Paul like he was a squeegee man soliciting drivers on the Queensboro Bridge.
Giuliani needed a score after the first debate's wishy-washy answer about overturning Roe versus Wade.
It would be okay.
Today's stories say that Giuliani helped himself out of the hole he had created in that first debate.
But hold on, because even though there were a hundred stories about his bumble, a Pew poll shows that half of Republican voters can't even tell you which candidates think what about abortion.
Relatively few ordinary voters know that he stumbled.
Alan Abramowitz, is a professor of political science at Emory University.
He says that debates in May, eight months before the first primaries are to be held, are fine exercises for the press and the candidates themselves, but they're barely registering to the voters.
In 2003, the first debates took place in September, four months before voting.
George W.
Bush didn't face off against his rivals for the Republican nomination until December of 1999.
In May of 1999, if someone told political analyst Stu Rothenberg where are the candidates stood he'd say, come on, it's May.
So what about where they stand in May of 2007?
I say, come on, it's May.
I really think voters won't focus on this.
And I'm specifically talking about folks in Iowa and New Hampshire, and those are the people that really matter.
I don't think they're going to focus on this until November, December, January.
You can push up the campaign season - the donors will come aboard, the consultants will be available for hire, but Rothenberg thinks the voters just have their own rhythms.
Look, you could take your summer vacation in March, it won't make the beaches warm.
But Jennifer Duffy of the Cook Political Report has different take.

Duffy looks at polls where voters are professing that they're interested, and thinks this is a new world with new venues of communication and a new type of voter who can lightly grace on political information without necessarily taking huge gulps.
Here's another analogy.
That is there are more models of cars and voters are literally in the showroom kicking the tires.
And, you know, they commit to one and they go away, and they say maybe not and they come back to see what they have that's new.
That's where I think Republican primary voters are right now.
I get it, so it's such like any other kind of consumerism.
Consumerism in the years 2007 is tons of choices, and lots of time, and lots of modes of communication to make up your mind about the choice.
You're welcome.
Yes.
Actually I participated in elections when many Iranians came to elect someone who had, you know, different ideas and who had a very good background and very good resume.
And when he was mayor of Tehran, he did a lot for this city.
And he was also governor of the Ardabil province.
That was why many Iranians wanted to make a new decision and wanted to bring someone new, like what they did in bringing President Khatami some eight years ago.
They were all looking for change.
Even though he is much more conservative than Khatami was and may institute some religious reforms to the government there.
Actually, as an Iranian, I think that, you know, the situation now in Iran has changed a lot with what it was some eight years ago.
And, you know, people have more social freedom.
And I think the new president will not, you know, limit the situation and will not put more restrictions on the people.
I think his initial schedule is to bring some, you know, new ways of economical schedules for the people.
That is what has been considered, you know, more important for people rather than, for example, the social freedom because we have it.
We are looking for something that we don't have, and that is why, I think, nothing will change, and the situation, in my opinion, is going to be better.
So you're confident you won't lose any of your freedoms?
Well, it seems very unlikely, but I cannot, you know, 100 percent say that nothing will happen.
He's president of all the Iranians.
I mean, he's not just the president of those who supported him.
He is now president of all Iranians, and he should work for the good of all country, not only for the good of, you know, some people and some supporters.
You mentioned the nuclear issue.
The West is quite concerned.
What do you think of opening up the UN seals on the plants in Isfahan?
As a country, we have the right to use different kinds of energy.
The government is saying that we use this nuclear energy in a peaceful way.
So if we can benefit nuclear energy in peaceful ways, we have to continue it, even if there are pressures from the international society.
Amir Aram is an Iranian college student and English translator.
He joined us from Tehran, Iran.
Thank you very much for joining us.
Thank you.
It's been my pleasure.
President Trump says he will pull the U.S.
out of a landmark climate agreement negotiated with nearly 200 countries.
The U.S.
will join Syria and Nicaragua as the only countries to reject the Paris accord.
But lawmakers in California are doubling their efforts to make the state an environmental leader.
The legislature is considering a series of bills that would insulate California from actions in Washington.
State senator Kevin de Leon is a Democrat from Los Angeles.
He is the leader of Democrats in the California State Senate and joins us now.
Welcome to the program.
Hi, Robert.
How are you doing?
California obviously has the biggest economy of any state.
If it were independent, it's often said it would be the fifth-biggest economy in the world.
Are you trying to position California on the world stage as a foil to Washington?

Well, listen; we're not looking for a fight with Washington and specifically Donald Trump, but we have successfully delinked and decoupled carbon from GDP in California, which means we actually have lowered our greenhouse gas emissions while, at the same time, we have grown our economy to be the sixth-largest economy in the world.

And there's only five economies in this world larger than California - the United States, Japan, China, Germany, on a good day - depending on the fluctuations of the sterling - United Kingdom, and it's California.

Two days ago, the California State Senate passed legislation that would make it easier for the state to maintain current environmental standards and policies despite what the federal government might do.
What exactly are you trying to preserve there?
What's at issue?
Well, we're moving 100 percent clean energy by the year 2045.
And the reason why we're doing so is that we have created 500,000 new jobs in the clean energy space.
And I want to put this in context for all Americans.
We have 10 times more jobs in California in the clean energy space than there are coal mining jobs in the entire country.
And that's an astonishing number.
So a withdrawal from the Paris accords would be devastating, I believe, to the economy of California.
And that's why we are moving fast forward.
We're forging ahead with or without Washington's help.
But when you say reaching 100 percent renewable energy by 2045, as of December, you were at 27 percent renewable.
Do you really think that's a realistic target, especially if the administration in Washington isn't especially helping you in that direction?
Oh, very much so because we're not dependent on the administration in Washington to help reach our target goals when it comes to renewable portfolio standard.
We would predict by 2022, 2024, the investor-owned utilities in California will hit probably 50 percent.
They're on a fast pace.
I give them a lot of credit because we have sent the right market signals that attracts necessary capital that has created technologies necessary to reach our emissions target goals.
But this is the difference, Robert, when you move forward policies that are very intentional and purposeful to create jobs and to reduce carbon emissions, unlike what's happening in Washington.
When you - you spoke of how many clean energy jobs there are in California.
Are you at all concerned that withdrawal from the Paris Agreement might reduce U.S.
demand for clean energy services or products or just energy and that that might in fact cost California jobs?
Well, it is very concerning to me because I think the Trump administration and Congress continue to surrender our nation's long-standing role as a global leader.
What is happening right now is that we have President Trump literally serving the clean energy leadership mantle on a silver platter to the Chinese.
The Chinese are more than happy to assume the No. 1 role as the global leader when it comes to climate change and clean energy.
Will that have any impact on California's economy - without a doubt.
But that's why we're moving quickly with 100 percent renewable portfolio standard clean energy to try to blunt as many potential job losses as possible due to Donald Trump's decision.

Or the Oakland Crybabies or the Dallas Crybabies or - Myron had wonderful expressions (unintelligible) his way of describing the opponent as only a commentator for the local team will have.

That voice of his became part of his trademark, and it was his mm-ahs(ph) and where he might have been pausing for a moment to gather a thought, or when he thought something was terrible, he would say, that's a bunch of gorgonzola.
And everyone would immediately think of the smell of gorgonzola and realize that yeah, that does stink, and he would go on.
But that was Myron.
He had great color but he had wonderful insight, he was a wonderful reporter, and he was uniquely Pittsburgh.
And so there was connection between all the fans in Pittsburgh and Myron Cope and the players.
Well, Lynn Swann, we've certainly enjoyed you sharing your memories of Myron Cope with us today.
Thank you so much.
Thank you, Jacki.
Lynn Swann is a hall of fame wide receiver who played his entire career with the Pittsburgh Steelers.
And all of those home games were announced by Myron Cope.
